title: How Newcastle brothers Sean and Matty Longstaff became the talk of the Toon
text:
It was in this very room at Newcastle United’s training ground eight years ago, a waiting area attached to the indoor pitch, that an academy coach told Matty Longstaff he was not good enough for his hometown club.

Now, the 19-year-old sits here alongside sibling Sean, 21, the most talked about footballing brothers in the country.

That is what happens when a teenager scores the winning goal against Manchester United on his Premier League debut with his brother by his side in midfield.

Today, Matty and Sean Longstaff are the most talked about footballing brothers in the country

It is Sean, though, who takes us back to 2011 and a car journey along the Coast Road to the family home in North Shields.

‘The night he was rejected I was in the car with him, and he was crying. From that point, he said nobody is going to be able to do this to me again.

‘He worked so hard. It felt like everything had been building to that moment when he scored. It was unbelievable. Even now, I’m getting a bit emotional talking about it.’

As Sean’s voice wavers, Matty takes over. Mum Michelle was right when she told Sportsmail last week, ‘They’ve always had each other’s back’.

’They pulled me in here and said, “Look, thanks for coming, but we’re not going to keep you”,’ Matty recalls.

That is what happens when a teenager scores the winning goal against Manchester United

‘I walked out crying. When you look back, it probably fired me up to get to where I am. It really p***ed me off. What I’ve done since then, it all comes from that moment.

‘Sean was still in the academy and I’d be here almost every night when he was training. I would have my little ball on the touchline and used to think, “I wish I was playing for Newcastle”.

‘Aged 13 I was back. I had more fire in my belly, I didn’t want to be rejected ever again.’

The goal. It was nil-nil after 72 minutes when the ball rolled into Matty’s path, 25 yards out at the Gallowgate End.

‘I shouted to him, “Just hit it!”,’ says Sean. Hit it he did, beyond David de Gea and into the bottom corner. Cue pandemonium.

‘I’ve had that feeling before, but for him to do that on his debut against Manchester United, the emotion was crazy. I actually froze for a second. I didn’t know what do, I didn’t know whether to just fall down on my knees!

It was nil-nil after 72 minutes when the ball rolled into Matty’s path (left), 25 yards out

‘I filled up, I thought I was going to cry - and you can’t do that in the middle of the pitch! I had to jump on someone and hide. It was pure happiness.’

What was it like for the scorer?

‘From the moment I struck it, I can’t remember much. It was the loudest roar I’ve ever heard from the Gallowgate. And then they’re singing your name, you just think, “This is absolutely mental”.’

Call it innocence - or perhaps more human decency - but there is genuine appreciation and wonderment between the brothers at where they now find themselves, especially given that one year ago they were playing together in the Checkatrade Trophy at Grimsby in front of 500 fans.

Matty tells one story that captures their boyish charm.

‘This might sound dead stupid, but the thing that calmed my nerves down was when I walked out with the mascot and started playing passes with him!

‘I was thinking, “Just concentrate on the pass, get some good touches in here”. You’re like, “I know it’s just a little kid, but I might as well make my passes pretty good”.’

Matty Longstaff, Sean Longstaff and Milly Longstaff pictured with their grandad

He needn’t have worried. His first pass was 40 yards and cross-field, straight to a team-mate. It set the tone for a man-of-the-match display, merited regardless of the Roy of the Rovers storyline that would emerge.

Afterwards, the brothers gave a joyous television interview which Gary Neville said should be shown to all young players.

‘I got man-of-the-match, but I thought Sean was the best player by a mile, so I've still got a bit of catching up to do,’ says Matty. ‘A couple of times when I went a bit headless chicken he was there to cover.’

His brother disagrees: ‘I couldn't have done that at 19. He's controlled the tempo of a Premier League game on his debut. He’s miles ahead of where I was at his age.

‘It fills you with pride. I remember thinking in the tunnel, “This is the best seat in the house, getting to watch Matty walk out for the first time at St James’ Park, as a brother and team-mate”.

‘If you’d told us a year ago this was going to happen, we both would have laughed. It’s crazy.’

One year ago they played together in the Checkatrade Trophy at Grimsby in front of 500 fans

In the hours after Manchester United, Newcastle fans asked on social media if there were any more Longstaff brothers.

One former Newcastle team-mate, Cal Roberts, tweeted: ‘Shelly and Davey have some DNA mind!’.

Shelly is mum Michelle, a fine netball player. Davey, meanwhile, is dad David, the first ice hockey player to win 100 caps for Great Britain. There is also sister Milly, 15, a rising county-level netball star.

What does she think of her brothers’ success?

‘She probably gets a bit annoyed in school when people are talking about us,’ says Matty. ‘The worst thing is, she’s probably the best sporting one in the family, she’s just a lot lazier, she doesn’t like to run around as much as we do!’

The love for their sister is clear. ‘Milly is great,’ says Sean. ‘She has been dragged to football ever since she was three.

Matty's first pass was 40 yards and cross-field, straight to a team-mate against the Red Devils

‘But it’s funny, you look at the Neville family - the brothers played in the Premier League and their sister played netball for England. So we’ve said to Milly, “We’ve done our little bit, it’s up to you now!”. She’s amazing, though, we can’t thank her enough for the sacrifices she’s made.’

The Longstaffs were fortunate that their corner house had a garden wrapped around it, be that for football, netball or cricket. The brothers, it is said, could have made it as professional cricketers.

‘I used to spend hours bowling at Matty and could never get him out,’ says Sean. ‘There was a time when he gave up football to see if he could make it at cricket. My dad had to have a little word…’

Matty laughs. ‘People were telling me I could go to the very top. I told my dad I might concentrate on cricket and he gave me a clip round the ear!’

It set the tone for a man-of-the-match display, merited regardless of the Roy of the Rovers line

As recently as two years ago Durham wanted to take Sean on trial.

‘It was finals day at Tynemouth Cricket Club and some of the Durham coaches were asking about me,’ he says. ‘The guys from Tynemouth just laughed, “If you can persuade him to leave Newcastle and play cricket, then best of luck to you!”.’

Michelle says her sons ‘genuinely love each other’ - they blush, yet accept the suggestion - but there were fights, too, indicative of their competitive spirit.

Sean says: ’My mam had to go into Newcastle and the coaches had a word with us, “You need to behave at home and stop fighting!”.

‘We realised we had to help each other more than fight each other. There’s not loads of people you can trust in life. Now, I know my brother will have my back, every step of the way.’
description: INTERVIEW BY CRAIG HOPE: It was in this very room at Newcastle United's training ground eight years ago, that an academy coach told Matty Longstaff he was not good enough.
authors: Craig Hope For The Daily Mail
